awd_titl_txt: SPX: Collaborative Research: Memory Fabric: Data Management for Large-scale Hybrid Memory Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
New large-scale high performance computing systems being developed for the national labs and by US industry, combine heterogeneous memory components, accelerators and accelerator-near memory, and programmable high-performance interconnects. These memory-rich designs are attractive as they provide the compute-near-data capacity needed for improving the time to scientific discovery, and for supporting new classes of latency-sensitive data-intensive applications. However, existing software stacks are not equipped to deal with the heterogeneity and complexity of these machine designs, which impacts application performance and machine efficiency. The Memory Fabric (MF) solution developed in this project provides new abstractions and mechanisms that permit the systems software stacks to gain deeper insight into applications' data usage patterns and requirements, and to coordinate the decisions concerning how data should be distributed across different memories, or exchanged along different interconnection paths. 

The Memory Fabric (MF) architecture introduces new data-centric abstractions, memory object and memory object flow, and accompanying memory and communications management methods. The higher-level information captured in the new abstractions empowers the MF runtime to better guide the underlying memory and interconnect management, and to mask the complexities of the underlying memory substrate. Additional benefits are derived from use of near-memory-fabric computation, including via dynamically inserted application-specific codes, which further specialize and accelerate the operations carried out by MF. MF is evaluated using several important application domains, including big data learning and analytics, and traditional high-performance scientific simulations. Its benefits include gains in application performance and resource efficiency, while shielding applications and application developers from the underlying machine details.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The development of large-scale systems for national labs and US industry involves the integration of heterogeneous memory components, accelerators, accelerator-near memory, and programmable high-performance interconnects. These memory-rich designs offer significant advantages by providing ample data capacity, which improves the speed of scientific discoveries and supports latency-sensitive data-intensive applications. However, the existing software stacks are not able to fully handle the heterogeneity and complexity of these machine designs, resulting in suboptimal application performance and machine efficiency.


The intellectual merit of our project is rooted in the creation of a comprehensive solution called Memory Fabric (MF), which introduces new abstractions and mechanisms to empower system software stacks. MF enables deeper insights into the data usage patterns and requirements of applications, facilitating informed decisions on data distribution across different memory modules and efficient data exchange through interconnection paths. Our project's specific contributions encompass multiple aspects: (1) the development of intelligent methods to manage complex and heterogeneous memory fabric resources, resulting in substantial improvements in application performance and system efficiency; (2) the establishment of mechanisms for native data structures and domain-specific runtimes (like MPI, RPC, Key-Value Store, NVMe, etc.), enabling more effective programming of underlying memory fabric resources and achieving enhanced performance and efficiency; (3) thorough characterization of the impact of emerging hardware and software stack complexity on real-world data-intensive and high-performance computing workloads; and (4) valuable insights on how to leverage the programmability of Memory Fabric (MF) in complex application workflows and system-level management of intricate resources, opening up promising directions for future research.


The broader impacts of our project extend beyond the research itself. We actively disseminate our findings through publications, tutorials,  presentations at renowned international conferences and workshops, and numerous invited talks. Moreover, we contribute to the open-source community by sharing software artifacts and experimental data generated during our research. This project has provided support for several PhD dissertations, including those of students from underrepresented groups in computing, fostering diversity and inclusion in the field. The outcomes of our research have gained recognition through multiple awards and accolades, including Best (Student) Paper Awards and finalists for our participating PhD students. Additionally, we have established collaborative relationships with industry partners and National Labs, facilitating technology transfer and maximizing the impact of our completed research.
